intro: Part time computer science student, part time satellite IT support, part time party thrower.

post.body: Apparently Youtube has lost interest in smaller creators. Remember the days when you could have only 5 views on your videos and still have them monetized?

Made a video about how I still can track the temperature of my old apartment, two years after I moved out. Everything thanks to the power of Internet of Things! 
http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/?Video=1516553946_195oGGXB8AhwWSoXFHpbVT4TL4wLi1Af5e

@ZeroLSTN: Is it only me who are having some trouble with ZeroLSTN on my Zeronet proxy? I'm running Apache with mod_proxy, and apparently the proxy does not forward CORS headers properly. I'll have to investigate more...but strange that it happens only with ZeroLSTN.

How did Windows 10 Fall Creators Upgrade succeed for you people? I received it today (without any option to postpone), first itasked for a product key (which I don't have, as nowadays they are always hidden in the BIOS away from the user). Then, it created a duplicate of EVERY app I have on my desktop ðŸ™„ Glad I'm running Arch on my main machine.
Happy Easter holidays everyone, remember to keep your bonfires burning! (Picture is from last week though, students in Finland like to start celebrations early)
The single day of summer is happening in Finland today. I'm preparing for winter already.

Just replaced my 8 year old _Microsoft Wireless Desktop 3000_ from 2010 (top) with the new _Microsoft Wireless Desktop 3050_ (bottom). The old set was quite worn and looked dirty even after being cleaned, but otherwise I have really liked it so I replaced it with the same model.

Besides, the 3050 comes with many cool features not found on the 3000, such as a Windows 10 logo on the Windows-key instead of a Windows 7 logo, and also AES encryption which should be much harder to crack than the old encryption algorithm.

Is UPS tracking information always this bad? They'll indeed be in quite a hurry if they think they'll be able to get a parcel from Germany to Finland before midnight, that's in 3 hours.

And then I paid 90 â‚¬ fee for next-day express shipping.
Because of the current heatwave in Scandinavian countries, hosting a server in your apartment with no AC can be a bit problematic when temperatures indoors rise above 35 Â°C.
An update from the latest bonfire we were having in our back yard.

comment.body: I assume it will work as it does now with Tor, that you can have Clearnet, Tor, and I2P in use at the same time, in order to be able to reach all nodes no matter what connection method they are using. These nodes that are running multiple protocols, will ensure that data from an I2P node will be synced to Clearnet and Tor nodes, and vice versa.

Tor is already installed by default when using the Windows package (I think, I don't use Windows myself). So I see no reason why Zeronet couldn't come with I2P enabled by default as well. As Git Center mentioned, I2P is just another transport layer, you can compare it with IPv4 and IPv6, they are different transport layers as well, yet nodes with IPv4, IPv6 or both will get the same data synced eventually.
There are some books on IFS: http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/

The best solution is to only use the outermost one as a router. Any extra routers you should configure to "Bridge mode", then you'll only have to do port forwarding on the outermost router. Also you will get better network performance as packets only have to be processed by the outer router, the extra routers will just forward packets without doing any processing on them.
Great to hear that also younger people still use IRC
What software are you other people using for your Zeronet proxies? Maybe Apache is not that common after all...

Okay, thanks! I resolved it for now by adding the Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * header for all pages in my Apache config - but that does not feel very secure. I'll see if I can implement the nginx-solution for Apache, but I'm running some 10 other websites as well, so moving everything to Nginx is too much of a change for me right now.
Yes, that did activate it in the end. But still not a very smooth user experience. Wish that "do it later" button would have been available when it started the upgrade.
Some people have too much time though, when they post some 10-20 times during a time period of only 1 hour. Like you sometimes can see here or on [KopyKate](/big.kopykate.bit/?Latest).

Just make a policy on ZeroMe saying that all NSFW content must be marked clearly, and just ban all users not adhering to this.

Also, uploading only a picture without any descriptive text should not be encouraged, so I'm in favor of introducing a minimum length for posts.

Zeronet will have a much harder time gaining popularity without a filter for NSFW content, because most people won't be comfortable showing it to friends & family if there's a high likelihood they will encounter porn during the demo.

@Orbit: Do you think it matters if the image is a bit blurred, if it still is sharp enough that you can tell it is porn? A person looking above your shoulder will still notice that you are watching (blurry) porn.

I think the best way is to add support for tagging NSFW content in the hubs, then each client (ZeroMe, [Sakana](/sakana.bit/), or clones of these) can decide if/how they treat the NSFW tag.

@Citycourt: Well, the "server" is only some 20 watts, but the temperature measurement was done very close to the ceiling, right above the refrigerator. This helped to keep the temperature maybe 5Â°C above the rest of the apartment.

@Citycourt: The delivery was split into 3 separate packages, if I remember correctly one was delivered on Friday and the rest on the next Monday. The order was audio equipment for a gig scheduled for Wednesday, so I had plenty of margin for delays anyway.
@Styromaniac: it's not legal, no. It was of course a stupid thing to do, because the smoke can be seen from far away and anyone can pinpoint the location.
